newsitem.title: USA: Seragen psoriasis drug tops placebo.
newsitem.headline: Seragen psoriasis drug tops placebo.

text.p: Seragen Inc said on Wednesday that psoriasis patents receiving a four-week treatment of its DAB389IL-2 receptor active protein in a Phase II clinical trial showed an improvement compared with patients receiving a placebo.
Dr Jerry Bagel, a dermatologist who conducted the trial, found that 12 of 27 patients who received at least one dose of DAB289IL-2 showed at least a 50 percent improvement in treating the disease.
Only three of 12 patients who received the placebo showed similar improvments, Seragen said.

"Patient improvement, as measured by change in the standard psoriasis severity index, was comparable in two separate studies of the drug," Bagel, director of the Psoriasis Treatment Center of Central New Jersey, said in a statement.
The Phase II study tested doses of 5, 10 and 15 micrograms per kilogram per day, Seragen said.
Seragen said it has now initiated a dose escalation study to evaluate the potential for anti-psoriatic effects starting at lower doses of DAB389IL-2.
